thread.title: 100 years of the world's most glamorous women
thread.title_full: 100 years of the world's most glamorous women

title: 100 years of the world's most glamorous women
text:
100 years of the world's most glamorous women By Jamie Fullerton, CNN Updated 0129 GMT (0929 HKT) February 6, 2017 
Chat with us in Facebook Messenger. Find out what's happening in the world as it unfolds. Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Albert Watson, American Vogue, May 1977 – "Coming into Fashion: A Century of Photography at Condé Nast," a new exhibition in Beijing, brings together images from fashion titles including Vogue, Vanity Fair and Glamour. Hide Caption 1 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Sebastian Kim, Teen Vogue, January 2011 – Teen Vogue launched in the US in 2004 as a sister publication to its fashion titan parent title. Hide Caption Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Peter Lindbergh, Vogue Italia, March 1989 – Peter Lindbergh is often credited with inventing the supermodel. Hide Caption 3 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Erwin Blumenfeld, American Vogue, March 1945 – A shot taken by Erwin Blumenfeld for the March 1945 issue of American Vogue. Hide Caption 4 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography David Bailey, American Vogue, April 1962 – David Bailey took this photo in 1962, when Vogue was looking to edgier young photographers for more natural fashion photography. Hide Caption 5 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Constantin Joffé, American Vogue, September 1945 – However, Constantin Joffé toyed with the idea of street photography as early as the 1940s. Hide Caption 6 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Edward Steichen, American Vogue, December 1923 – In the 1920s, Vogue used New York stage performers for their models, arguably kicking off the fashion industry's obsession with celebrities. Hide Caption 7 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography John Rawlings, American Vogue, March 1943 – A photo by John Rawlings for the March 1943 edition of American Vogue. Hide Caption 8 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Deborah Turbeville, American Vogue, May 1975 – This shot by Deborah Turbeville was part of a controversial series. Many subscribers canceled their magazine orders, outraged by the alleged lewdness of her photos. Hide Caption 9 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Clifford Coffin, American Vogue, June 1949 – A photo by Clifford Coffin for American Vogue, June 1949. Hide Caption 10 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Norman Parkinson, Glamour, October 1949 – This shot by Norman Parkinson is one of few non-Vogue images being exhibited. Hide Caption 11 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Sølve Sundsbø, Love, Spring/Summer 2011 – This photo by Sølve Sundsbø appeared in the Spring/Summer 2011 edition of Love magazine. Hide Caption 12 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Miles Aldridge, Vogue Italia, September 2002 – Vogue Italia has a reputation for running less conventional shoots than other editions of the magazine. Hide Caption 13 of 15 Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Guy Bourdin, French Vogue, February 1955 – This famous image by Guy Bourdin appeared in the February 1955 edition of French Vogue. Hide Caption Photos: A century of Conde Nast photography Inez & Vinoodh, French Vogue, October 2002 – A more out-there photo composition by Inez & Vinoodh. Hide Caption 15 of 15 Beijing, China (CNN) An exhibition showcasing 100 years of fashion photography from the Condé Nast magazine stable -- ranging from 1920s shots of Broadway actresses to some of the most recognizable photos of the supermodel era -- has opened in Beijing. JUST WATCHED
